Now on to some news from the literary world.
Nigerian writer and poet Chinua Achebe was recently awarded the prestigious Man Booker International Prize.
It's only given once every two years to a living author in honor of his or her body of work.
Winners get 60,000 British pounds or about U.S.$119,000.
Most importantly Achebe's win raises Africa's profile in the literary world and beyond.
His debut novel ""Things Fall Apart,"" published in 1958, won him global acclaim and is widely considered a masterpiece.
The book has been translated into 50 languages and sold more than 10 million copies.
Since then he has written other novels, poetry, children's books and criticism.
He's currently a professor at Bard College in New York State.
I recently spoke with Chinua Achebe by phone from his home.
He described the story behind the protagonist in ""Things Fall Apart."" Okonkwo is a prosperous farmer, husband and father in Nigeria during the colonial era, and he's not a kind man.
The reason he's a strong man or he thinks he's a strong man is that his father had been the opposite, had been a man of peace, had been a man of few words, and he was not a success.
He was not prosperous.
And it is this fact — the fact of a man who didn't satisfy the expectations of his son — that is the crux of this story.
And so we have a fun within rebellion against his father and want to be the opposite of what his father was.
And so you immediately have a one family succeeding another and being the opposite.
This is one of the things that I play with in my writing.
Achebe didn't write any novels between 1966 and 1988.
